claim.text: CQCC significantly outperforms MFCC in the classification of neurodegenerative disorders, demonstrating absolute improvements of 5.6% and 7.7% with Random Forest and SVM classifiers respectively.
claim.exact_quote: the proposed CQCC features outperform the baseline MFCC features with an absolute increment of 5.6% and 7.7% on RF and SVM classifiers, respectively.

evidence.evidence_text: CQCC achieved absolute improvements of 5.6% with Random Forest and 7.7% with SVM classifiers respectively, in comparison to MFCC.
evidence.location: Table 5: Classification Accuracy of RF and SVM for Different Features
evidence.exact_quote: proposed CQCC features outperform the baseline MFCC features with an absolute increment of 5.6% and 7.7% on RF and SVM classifiers, respectively.

conclusion.limitations: Lack of broader dataset analysis beyond the mentioned disorders and classifiers

claim.text: CQCC combined with SVM achieved the highest accuracy of 86.1% in distinguishing ALS from Parkinson's patients, showing superior performance over other acoustical features.
claim.exact_quote: CQCC yields the highest accuracy with SVM (86.1%) and consistently performs well with RF (80.5%), indicating its superior capability in capturing the nuanced differences in the vocal characteristics associated with these diseases.

evidence.evidence_text: CQCC combined with SVM achieved the highest accuracy of 86.1% in distinguishing ALS from Parkinson's patients, showing superior performance over other acoustical features.
evidence.location: Table 6: Classification Accuracy of RF and SVM for Different Features
evidence.exact_quote: CQCC yields the highest accuracy with SVM (86.1%) and consistently performs well with RF (80.5%), indicating its superior capability in capturing the nuanced differences in the vocal characteristics associated with these diseases.

conclusion.limitations: Performance specifics of CQCC with SVM not detailed for conditions outside ALS and Parkinson's

claim.text: CQCC provides a more effective feature set for neurodegenerative disorder classification than traditional acoustic metrics, evidenced by enhanced classification robustness across different datasets.
claim.exact_quote: The findings underscore that CQCCs emerged as the most effective feature, achieving the highest accuracy in classification tasks.

evidence.evidence_text: CQCC demonstrates enhanced performance over traditional acoustic measures across different datasets, validating its effectiveness in complex pathological classifications.
evidence.exact_quote: Comparison with MFCC further validated the superiority of CQCC, showing considerable improvements in both the RF and SVM classifiers. Furthermore, the evaluation in new databases (D1 and D3) reaffirmed the robustness of CQCC in handling complex pathological classifications.

conclusion.limitations: Assessment of classification robustness across datasets not fully detailed

claim.text: The study presents the first application of sustained vowel sounds with the Form-Invariance property of CQT for the classification of multiple neurodegenerative disorders.
claim.exact_quote: To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this is the first study of it;s (sic) kind on sustained vowel sounds for multi neurodegenerative disorder classification and analysis.

evidence.evidence_text: This study is the first to apply the Form-Invariance property of CQT with sustained vowel sounds for the classification of multiple neurodegenerative disorders, using CQCC feature extraction.
evidence.limitations: Evidence is based on author assertions, with no direct comparison to previous research methods.
evidence.exact_quote: To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this is the first study of its kind on sustained vowel sounds for multi neurodegenerative disorder classification and analysis.

conclusion.limitations: Claim of novelty not substantiated with references to previous studies or techniques
